pageData.text: This investigation uses <button class='glossary-text'>calorimetry</button> to measure the heat of solution for two salt compounds commonly used in hot packs and cold packs. You will perform a graphical analysis of the calorimetry data for an endothermic and exothermic salt and predict how many grams of each salt are required to achieve a specific temperature when activated. After determining the heats of solution for both compounds, you will design a proposal for constructing a hot pack and a cold pack containing 100 g of water.

pageData.text: Historically, <button class='glossary-text'>calorimetry</button> was the method used to determine the kilocalories in food items. Calorimetry was used until there was a clear weakness found with the method: using calorimetry for food caloric content was based on flammability and food contains ingredients that are flammable but are not absorbed into the blood stream. An example of this would be fiber. Because of this flammability, their energy contribution was included in caloric measurements even when they do not absorb into the bloodstream. This led to the development of the more contemporary Atwater indirect system. <span className=bodyParaLineBreak>The Atwater system is more theoretical in that it uses average values of 4 Kcal/g for protein, 4 Kcal/g for carbohydrate, 9 Kcal/g for fat, and 7 Kcal/g for alcohol.<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>While the industry has moved away from calorimetric methods, it is important to note that even the Atwater indirect system is based off information obtained from a <button class='glossary-text'>calorimeter</button>. Using the Atwater indirect system, a doughnut has the same number of kilocalories as a stick of dynamite. The dynamite releases all its energy immediately upon ignition, the doughnut over time.

1Schwarez, J. (2018, September 7). How is the caloric value of food determined? . McGill University Office for Science and Society.https://www.mcgill.ca/oss/article/nutrition/how-caloric-value-food-determined

pageData.text: When people sprain their ankle they are often given an instant cold pack to prevent swelling at the injury site. After 48–72 hours, a hot pack can be applied to relieve pain and stimulate blood flow for faster healing. These packs are activated by breaking an internal water pouch, which mixes with a salt contained in the outer bag. The amount of heat absorbed or released depends on the salt used and can be determined by the science of <button class='glossary-text'>chemical thermodynamics</button>. <span className=bodyParaLineBreak>Chemical thermodynamics is the study of energy changes that accompany physical and chemical transformations. These changes occur through the generation or absorption of a quantifiable amount of heat (q). If heat is generated during the reaction or physical change, it is an <button class='glossary-text'>exothermic reaction</button>. If the heat is absorbed or needs to be added to the reaction or physical change, then it is called an <button class='glossary-text'>endothermic reaction</button>.

pageData.text: Scientists use the term to measure the total energy of a system at constant pressure. Enthalpy also accounts for any change in volume during a reaction, which is important when dealing with gas reactions. The equation for the enthalpy change of a reaction is:ΔH = Δq + PΔVWhere ΔH is the change in enthalpy, Δq is the heat change, P is pressure (which remains constant), and ΔV is the change in volume. In most , pressure and volume are constant. Therefore, the equation becomes: ΔH = ΔqEnthalpy is dependent on the amount of substance present. The enthalpy change for a reaction is generally written as a molar quantity. To calculate the molar enthalpy of a reaction, divide the reaction heat by the number of moles of reactant or product: ΔHrxn = qrxn/mol

Heat energy is always conserved within a system and all the parts of that system will adjust so that everything is the same temperature. For example, if a hot piece of copper metal is added to room temperature water, the heat energy transfers from the copper to the water. The energy transferred from the copper to the water because of the temperature difference is the heat (q). If the system is left undisturbed, the energy will continue to flow from the copper to the water until both are the same temperature, indicating that the system is at equilibrium.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Calorimetry</button> is the act of measuring heat energy. The magnitude and the direction of heat transfer can be determined by using a calorimeter. A calorimeter is an insulated apparatus designed to create a closed system by preventing heat from flowing in or out. In this lab the calorimeter is two foam coffee cups stacked together and placed in a 250-mL beaker. The double foam walls and the air surrounding the cups in the beaker insulate the system.

pageData.text: In this investigation, the temperature change that occurs when a salt is dissolved in water will be measured. The heat released or absorbed during the reaction will be calculated by measuring the temperature change. However, heat is not the same as temperature. Temperature measures how hot or cold the sample is and is independent of mass. Heat or heat energy measures the energy a sample contains. It is an extensive property and depends on the material quantity (mass). For example, a drop of boiling water and a gallon of boiling water both have a temperature of 100 °C, but the gallon of water has significantly higher heat energy because there is more of it.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>The amount of heat that is given off or absorbed by a substance depends on both the mass and the substance composition. Every substance has its own <button class='glossary-text'>specific heat (C<sub className=bodySubscript>p</sub>)</button>, which is defined as the amount of heat energy necessary to raise the temperature of 1 gram by 1 °C. The specific heat of water is 4.18 J/g °C, which means it takes 4.18 joules of energy to raise the temperature of 1 g of water by 1 °C. More examples of specific heat include aluminum, which has a specific heat of 0.22 cal/g °C or 0.91 J/g °C, and copper whose specific heat is 0.09 cal/g °C or 0.385 J/g °C. Water requires more energy to heat than aluminum and copper metal.

In the , a measured mass of water at a given temperature will be placed in the inner cup and a chemical will be added. When the chemical dissolves in the water the heat can either be transferred to the water or absorbed from the water by the act of chemical solvation. Since this reaction is carried out at constant (atmospheric) pressure, the heat of the reaction can be calculated using the change in temperature of the water.The heat transfer or change in for a reaction (qrxn) is related to the mass of the solution (m), the specific heat capacity of the solution at constant atmospheric pressure (Cp), and the temperature change (ΔT = Tfinal – Tinitial) as shown in Equation 1. The minus sign on the right side of the equation means that if a solute releases heat, the water will absorb it, and if a solute absorbs heat, the water will release it. If a reaction absorbs heat, it is considered This means that the reaction will be observed to cool. If a reaction releases heat it is meaning that the temperature increased.

Equation 1.qrxn = –(m × Cp × ΔT)No is a perfect insulator. There will be a small amount of energy transferred to and from the calorimeter. If the temperature of the reaction solution inside the calorimeter is higher than the calorimeter, some heat will be lost from the solution to heat up the calorimeter. Therefore, a calculation for the calorimeter itself must be added to the solution calculation on the right side of Equation 1, as shown in Equation 2.Equation 2.qrxn = –[(msolution × Cp solution × ΔTsolution) + (mcalorimeter × Cp calorimeter × ΔTcalorimeter)]Since the mass and of the calorimeter remain constant, they can be multiplied together to form another constant (m × Cp = C). C represents the heat capacity of the calorimeter with the unit J/ ºC in Equation 3.Equation 3.qrxn = –[(mwater × Cp water × ΔTwater) + (Ccalorimeter × ΔTcalorimeter)]
The change in temperature for the calorimeter is assumed to be the same as the change in temperature for water since they are in contact with each other.

In Activity 1, the heat capacity of the <button class='glossary-text'>calorimeter</button> will be determined by analyzing the temperature change of the cold water in the calorimeter when hot water is added. The difference between the heat lost by the hot water and the heat gained by the cold water will be due to the heat absorbed by the calorimeter.

A calibration curve is used to determine the heat capacity of the calorimeter. The calibration curve is a plot of the water temperature in the calorimeter as a function of time. Plotting the temperature as a function of time will determine the cooling rate of the mixture. You can accurately measure the initial mixing temperature by fitting the data with a linear trend line using Excel. Figure 2 shows a calibration curve generated by adding 50 g of 96 °C water to 50 g of 24 °C water. The initial temperature of the mixture should have been 60 °C [(96 + 24)/2 = 60]. The y-intercept from the linear trend curve is 57.4 °C and will represent Tfinal. ΔT(hot water) = 57.4 °C – 96 °C = –38.6 °CΔT(cold water) = 57.4 °C – 24 °C = 33.4 °CThe energy lost by this reaction (Δq(hot water) + Δq(cold water)) will be gained by the calorimeter (Δq(cal)), so the value of Δq(cal) should be set to be positive in Figure 3.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: graph of a calibration curve

Figure 3: Δq = C × ΔT × m
Δq(hot water) = 4.18 J/g °C × –38.6 °C × 50 g = –8,067 J
Δq(cold water) = 4.18 J/g °C × 33.4 °C × 50 g = 6,981 J
|Δq(hot water) + Δq(cold water)| = Δq(cal)
Energy gained by calorimeter = 1,086 J
Δq(cal) = 1,086 J = C(cal) × 33.4 °C
Ccal = 32.5 J/°C

pageData.question: 5.0 g of iron metal was heated from 20.2°C to 80.7°C. Approximately how much energy, in joules, was used to heat the iron? Assume the calorimeter is perfectly insulated. The specific heat of iron metal is 0.44 J/g•K.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text:
Cp = 0.44 J/g•K
Tfinal in K = 80.7 + 273 = 354°C
Tinitial in K = 20.2 + 273 = 293°C
ΔT = 354°C – 293°C = 61°C
m = 5.0 g
Δq = Cp × ΔT × m
Δq = (0.44 J/g•K) x (61 K) x (5.0 g) = 134.2 J = 130 J

pageData.question: 7.0 g of copper metal was heated from 39.0°C to 91.0°C. Approximately how much energy, in joules, was used to heat the copper? Assume the calorimeter is perfectly insulated. The specific heat of copper metal is 0.38 J/g°•C.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text:
Cp = 0.38 J/g•C
ΔT = 91°C – 39°C = 52°C
m = 7.0 g

Δq = Cp × ΔT × m
Δq = (0.38 J/g•°C) x (52°C) x (7.0 g) = 138.32 J = 140 J

pageData.desc: This map describes the procedural workflow for the first two activities of this investigation. To prepare, you will need to construct a calorimeter. In Activity 1, you will need to combine hot and cold water in the calorimeter. Then measure the change in water temperature over time. You will repeat this process for two trials. Then graph measurements as temperature versus time. Use a linear trend line to determine T0. Then calculate the average heat capacity of the calorimeter. In Activity 2, you will need to add water to the calorimeter. Then measure Ti . Then add calcium chloride to the calorimeter. Next measure Tf. Repeat this process for 3 different masses of calcium chloride. Then calculate the average enthalpy per mole of solution.

Construct a <button class='glossary-text'>calorimeter</button> by placing one foam cup inside another and placing these two cups inside a 250-mL beaker. Placing the two foam cups inside the beaker prevents the calorimeter from tipping over.

In Activity 1, you will determine the heat capacity of the <button class='glossary-text'>calorimeter</button> using a calibration curve. You will start by combining hot and cold water in the calorimeter and measuring the change in water temperature over time. Then, you will create a temperature versus time graph from the data and add a linear trend line. Using data from the trend line and your measurements, you will perform a series of calculations to determine the average heat capacity of the calorimeter.

pages.title: Heat Capacity of the Calorimeter (18 steps)

pageData.text: Measure 50.0 mL of water with a graduated cylinder and pour into the inner foam cup of the <button class='glossary-text'>calorimeter</button>. This will be the cold water.
Place the foam cup with the cold water inside the beaker.
Remember: 1 mL of water = 1 g of water
Stir the water with the thermometer until temperature is constant and record it as the initial temperature of the cold water (Tc) in Data Table 1B.
Fill a third foam cup ¾ full with the hottest tap water possible.
Take the temperature of the hot water. If the temperature is less than 80 °C, heat in a microwave with short bursts until it reaches 80 °C.

Measure 50.0 mL of the hot water with a graduated cylinder. Place a thermometer in the cylinder and gently stir to get a constant reading. The temperature should be 75–80 °C. Record this as the temperature of the hot water (Th) in Data Table 1B.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Quickly pour the 50.0 mL of hot water into the cold water and start a timer.
Gently stir the mixed water with the thermometer, and record the temperature at 1 minute and then at 1-minute intervals for 10 minutes in Data Table 1A.
Discard the water, dry the cup with a paper towel, and place it back in the calorimeter.
Repeat this activity, and collect a second set of data.
Create a spreadsheet and graph for the temperature versus time data.
Calculate the linear trend line and use the y-intercept to find the temperature at time 0 (T0) when the two volumes of water are mixed. Record this value in Data Table 1B.

Calculate the heat lost by hot water and record in Data Table 1B.
Δq(hot water) = C × ΔT × m

Calculate the heat gained by cold water and record in Data Table 1B.
Δq(coldwater) = C × ΔT × m

Calculate the heat gained by the calorimeter and record in Data Table 1B.
Δq(cal) = |Δq(hot water) + Δq(cold water)|

Calculate the temperature change of the calorimeter and record in Data Table 1B.
ΔTcal = T0 - Tc

Calculate the heat capacity (C) of the calorimeter in J/°C and record in Data Table 1B.
Ccal = Δq(cal) / ΔTcal

In Activity 2, you will determine the <button class='glossary-text'>enthalpy</button> of solution for calcium chloride using the <button class='glossary-text'>calorimeter</button>. You will start by measuring the temperature of the reaction before and after calcium chloride is added to the calorimeter. This will be repeated for two additional masses of calcium chloride. Then, you will perform a series of calculations to determine the average enthalpy per mole of solution.

pages.pageTitle:
A
 Enthalpy of Solution for Calcium Chloride (7 steps)

pageData.text: Measure 100 mL of pure or bottled water with a graduated cylinder, and pour it into the <button class='glossary-text'>calorimeter</button>.
Stir the water with a thermometer until the temperature is constant, and record it as the initial temperature (Ti) in Data Table 2.

This map describes the procedural workflow for the first two activities of this investigation. To prepare, you will need to construct a calorimeter. In Activity 1, you will need to combine hot and cold water in the calorimeter. Then measure the change in water temperature over time. You will repeat this process for two trials. Then graph measurements as temperature versus time. Use a linear trend line to determine T0. Then calculate the average heat capacity of the calorimeter. In Activity 2, you will need to add water to the calorimeter. Then measure Ti . Then add calcium chloride to the calorimeter. Next measure Tf. Repeat this process for 3 different masses of calcium chloride. Then calculate the average enthalpy per mole of solution.

This map describes the procedural workflow for the last two activities of this investigation. In Activity 3, you will need to add water to the calorimeter. Then measure Ti . Then add ammonium chloride to the calorimeter. Next measure Tf. Repeat this process for 3 different masses of ammonium chloride. Then calculate the average enthalpy per mole of solution. In Activity 4, you will need to graph ΔT versus mass for calcium chloride. Then graph ΔT versus mass for ammonium chloride. Next, determine the amount of compound needed to create a hot pack. Finally, determine the amount of compound needed to create a cold pack.

data.title: Calorimeter
data.content: An insulated apparatus designed to create a closed system by preventing heat from flowing in or out.

data.title: Calorimetry
data.content: The act of measuring heat energy.

data.title: Chemical thermodynamics
data.content: The study of energy changes that accompany physical and chemical transformations.

data.title: Endothermic reaction
data.content: A reaction that absorbs heat from the surroundings.

data.title: Enthalpy (H)
data.content: Measures the total energy of a system at constant pressure.

data.title: Exothermic reaction
data.content: A reaction that releases heat to the surroundings.

data.title: Specific heat (C<sub className=bodySubscript>p</sub>)
data.content: The amount of heat energy necessary to raise the temperature of 1 gram of a substance by 1 °C.
